block.p: Cendant Official Makes Bid To Regain Control of Avis Henry Silverman, the chief executive of Cendant, made a bid to regain control of the Avis Group Holdings, the nation's second largest rental car company, at a price the market immediately deemed too low.

The bid signals his return to the acquisition trail after two years of accounting problems that grew out of his biggest merger, with CUC International. Mr. Silverman offered about $740 million, or $29 a share, but investors bid up the shares of Avis $5, to $30.50. [Page C2.]

Suit Accuses BET of Evading Taxes A former chief financial officer for Black Entertainment Television plans to file a lawsuit contending that the company, its chairman, Robert L. Johnson, and its president, Debra Lee, made extensive efforts to evade the payment of some taxes. Mr. Johnson and Ms. Lee could not be reached for comment. [C2.]

Fast Appeal Urged in Microsoft Case The Justice Department, declaring that the outcome of the Microsoft antitrust case could affect nearly every person who uses a computer, urged the Supreme Court to hear the company's appeal quickly so ''that justice is not denied through delay.'' [C6.]

British Airways Grounds Concordes British Airways grounded its entire fleet of Concorde supersonic airliners after French and British investigators said they would urge the withdrawal of the airplane's airworthiness certification following last month's fatal Air France Concorde crash near Paris. [A1.]

Poor Retail Earnings Slow Markets Stocks declined on weakness in retail shares. The Dow dropped 109.14 points, or 1 percent, to 11,067.00. The S.& P. 500 fell 7.13 points, to 1,484.43. The Nasdaq composite index was up 1.97 points, to 3,851.66. [C10.]

A World View From a Bodega Ida L. Castro's parents came to New York from Puerto Rico in the 1930's and worked three jobs before they opened their own bodega. Ms. Castro says their belief in hard work and their dedication to education gave her a solid foundation. Now, she is the head of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. The Boss. [C7.]

AMF Is Pushed to Reorganize AMF Bowling, the largest operator of bowling alleys, has been given seven weeks to come up with a plan for reorganizing its debts or risk being pushed into bankruptcy court. [C8.]

Court Limits Cell Phone Monitoring An appeals court struck down part of a government order that had expanded the ability of law enforcement agents to monitor cell phone conversations of criminal suspects. [A20.]

Menem Sees Threat for Argentina The former president of Argentina, Carlos Saul Menem, has predicted that the country faces a devaluation and a depression unless President Fernando de la Rua either changes economic direction or adopts the United States dollar as the national currency. [C4.]

Concerns Raised on S.E.C. Proposal The chairman of Ernst & Young, the accounting firm that has supported the Securities and Exchange Commission's effort to tighten rules on auditor independence, said the commission's proposal goes too far and would create too much uncertainty about would be permitted.
